description.eng: A primitive meteorite, usually bearing chondrules, that has not experienced igneous differentiation on its parent body.
description.fr: Météorite primitive, portant généralement des chondrules, qui n'a pas subi de différenciation ignée sur son corps parent.

description.eng: Fragments of small asteroids, ejected from the main belt by a shock-collision between two asteroids, they are the most common: around 87% of meteorites.
description.fr: Fragments de petits astéroïdes, éjectés de la ceinture principale par un choc-collision entre deux astéroïdes, elles sont les plus fréquentes : environ 87% des météorites.

description.eng: The name (H for high) comes from their abundance of iron, compared to other ordinary chondrites. This element represents between 25 and 31% of the weight. More than half is present in metallic form, explaining the strong magnetism of these meteorites despite their stone appearance.
description.fr: Le nom (H pour high, « haut » en anglais) vient de leur abondance en fer, par rapport aux autres chondrites ordinaires. Cet élément représente entre 25 et 31 % du poids. Plus de la moitié est présent sous forme métallique, expliquant le fort magnétisme de ces météorites malgré leur apparence de pierre.

description.eng: Type H chondrite, from petrological type 3.
description.fr: Chondrite de type H, du type pétrologique 3.

description.eng: Type H chondrite, from petrological type 4.
description.fr: Chondrite de type H, du type pétrologique 4.

description.eng: Type H chondrite, from petrological type 5.
description.fr: Chondrite de type H, du type pétrologique 5.

description.eng: Type H chondrite, from petrological type 6.
description.fr: Chondrite de type H, du type pétrologique 6.

description.eng: Type H chondrite, from petrological type 7.
description.fr: Chondrite de type H, du type pétrologique 7.

Leur nom (L = "low", bas en anglais) vient de leur teneur en fer relativement faible, par rapport aux chondrites de type H, qui contiennent environ 20 à 25 % de fer en masse. Historiquement, les chondrites de type L ont été nommées chondrites à hypersthène ou chondrites à olivine et hypersthène en rapport aux minéraux dominants, mais ces désignations sont maintenant obsolètes.

LL est l'abréviation de l'anglais low (total) iron, low metal, soit une faible teneur en fer total et en fer métallique. Elles contiennent 19 à 22 % de fer total et seulement 0,3 à 3 % de fer métallique.

description.eng: A major class of chondrites that mostly have Mg/Si ratios near the solar value and oxygen isotope compositions that plot below the terrestrial fractionation line.

A major class of chondrites that mostly have sub-solar Mg/Si and refractory/Si ratios, oxygen isotope compositions that plot near the terrestrial fractionation line, and highly reduced mineral assemblages (containing little FeO, Si-bearing metal, and sulfides of elements normally considered lithophile.
A grouplet of chondrites with similarities to Kakangari, which do not fit into the major classes of chondrites such as carbonaceous, ordinary, or enstatite.

The Rumuruti (R) group of chondrites does not clearly belong to any of the major classes of chondrites (ordinary, carbonaceous, enstatite); R chondrites have sub-solar Mg/Si and refractory/Si ratios, oxygen isotope compositions that plot above the terrestrial fractionation line and ordinary chondrites, and highly oxidized mineralogy.
A piece of fusion crust that became detached from a chondrite.
A stony meteorite that lacks chondrules.
A stony meteorite that lacks chondrules and originated on a differentiated parent body.
A meteorite that has lost its chondritic texture due to heating and partial melting, but still has nearly chondritic composition.

Acapulcoites, named after the Acapulco, Mexico, fall of 1913, and lodranites, named after the Lodran, Pakistan, fall of 1868, are closely related, equigranular meteorites; acapulcoites are finer grained than lodranites and contain rare, relict chondrules, and there are transitional meteorites between the two types (e.g., EET 84302, GRA 95209). Mineral assemblages are similar to, but distinct from those of ordinary chondrites. Compositions are subchondritic, with lodranites showing a higher degree of fractionation.

Acapulcoites, named after the Acapulco, Mexico, fall of 1913. Contain rare, relict chondrules, and there are transitional meteorites between the two types (e.g., EET 84302, GRA 95209). Mineral assemblages are similar to, but distinct from those of ordinary chondrites.
Lodranites, named after the Lodran, Pakistan, fall of 1868. They show a higher degree of fractionation.

Brachinites, named after Brachina, a meteorite found in Australia in 1974, are olivine-rich achondrites that are relatively close to chondrites in many compositional properties, and so are frequently considered to be primitive achondrites. Their true origin is still an open question and not all brachinites may share the same origin.

Ureilites, named after the Novo-Urei, Russia, fall of 1886, are ultramafic achondrites that contain interstitial carbon as graphite or diamond. The majority consist of olivine + uninverted pigeonite. In a few, the pyroxene is augite and/or orthopyroxene instead. In addition, about 10% of ureilites are polymict breccias, containing a few percent of feldspathic material in addition to typical ureilitic components.

Winonaites, named after the Winona, Arizona, find of 1928, are equigranular rocks, some of which may contain relict chondrules, that have mineralogy and composition that are similar to chondrites.The mineral assemblage is more reduced than that of H chondrites. Winonaites are related to the silicate inclusions found in IAB complex irons.
A meteorite that is dominantly composed of Fe-Ni metal and that crystallized from a melt.

An association of iron meteorites, including the former groups IAB and IIICD. The new term "IAB complex" includes a variety of newly defined groups, including the "IAB main group", grouplets, and ungrouped meteorites (see Wasson and Kallemeyn (2002) Geochimica et Cosmochimica Acta, Vol. 66, No. 13, pp. 2445-2473.
An iron meteorite belonging to the main group (MG) of the IAB complex.
An iron meteorite belonging to the high-Au, high-Ni subgroup (sHH) of the IAB complex
An iron meteorite belonging to the high-Au, low-Ni subgroup (sHL) of the IAB complex.
An iron meteorite belonging to the low-Au, high-Ni subgroup (sLH) of the IAB complex.
An iron meteorite belonging to the low-Au, low-Ni subgroup (sLL) of the IAB complex.
An iron meteorite belonging to the low-Au, medium-Ni subgroup (sLM) of the IAB complex.
An iron meteorite possibly belonging to chemical group IAB.
An iron meteorite belonging to chemical group IC.
An iron meteorite belonging to chemical group IIAB.
An iron meteorite belonging to chemical group IIC.
An iron meteorite belonging to chemical group IID.
An iron meteorite belonging to chemical group IIE.
An iron meteorite belonging to chemical group IIF.
An iron meteorite belonging to chemical group IIG.
An iron meteorite belonging to chemical group IIIAB.
An iron meteorite belonging to chemical group IIICD.
An iron meteorite belonging to chemical group IIIE.
An iron meteorite belonging to chemical group IIIF.
An iron meteorite belonging to chemical group IVA.
An iron meteorite belonging to chemical group IVB.

Ataxites are a structural class of iron meteorites with a high nickel content and show no Widmanstätten patterns upon etching.
Ataxites are the most nickel-rich meteorites known; they usually contain over 18% nickel. The high nickel content is the reason that they do not develop a Widmanstätten structure, because in this case kamacite can be exsolved from taenite only at such a low temperature (below about 600°C) where diffusion is already too slow.
Most ataxites belong to the IVB group or are classified as "Iron, ungrouped" because they do not fit in any of the groups currently recognized by meteorite classification. Some ataxites belong to the IAB group and fall into the sHL (high-Au, low-Ni subgroup), sLH (low-Au, high-Ni subgroup), sHH (high-Au, high-Ni subgroup) and "ung" subgroup (does not fit any subgroup of IAB). Only a couple of ataxites have been classified into the IAB complex and the IIF, IVA, IIAB, IIIAB groups.
An obsolete term for an iron meteorite remarkable for a high proportion of nickel.

An older structural classification of iron meteorites based on the absence of the Widmanstätten pattern, which can be assessed from the appearance of polished cross-sections that have been etched with acid. They have a low abundance of nickel relative to iron.
A meteorite that is dominantly composed of Fe-Ni metal and that crystallized from a melt.

Octahedrite is a historical classification for iron meteorites based on structure. It shows a Widmanstätten pattern of kamacite exsolution lamellae out of taenite.
See also octahedrite (of Werner), a synonym of anatase.
A possible iron meteorite that has not been classified.
An iron meteorite that does not fit into any of the established chemical groups.
A highly altered object that is likely to have a meteoritic origin. These are dominantly (>95%) composed of secondary minerals formed from alteration after it landed.
A relict meteorite that originated as an H group ordinary chondrite.
A relict meteorite that originated as an iron meteorite.
A relict meteorite that originated as an OC group ordinary chondrite.
A relict meteorite that originated as an ureilite meteorite.
Stony-iron meteorites or siderolites are meteorites that consist of nearly equal parts of meteoric iron and silicates.
description.fr: Météorite composée pour moitié d'un alliage fer-nickel et pour moitié de silicates. Il s'agit en fait d'une météorite pierreuse à incrustations métalliques.

description.eng: A brecciated meteorite containing subequal silicate and metallic components; the silicates are dominantly igneous rock fragments.
A meteorite that is a mixture of metal and silicates (usually olivine grains).
A pallasite belonging to the Eagle Station chemical group
A pallasite belonging to the main chemical group.
A pallasite containing pyroxene as inclusions in the olivine crystals, as large grains in the nickel-iron matrix and as grains bordering the olivines.
A pallasite that is neither a member of the main group nor the Eagle Station grouplet, and is therefore ungrouped.
